Neither private dwellings, nor public buildings; neither ſex, nor age, nor religion, were the leaſt protection againſt their luſt or avarice.

The capital of the empire being thus ranſacked ſeveral times, and Italy overrun by barbarous invaders, under various denominations, from the remoteſt ſkirts of Europe; the weſtern emperors, for ſome time, continued to hold the title without the power of royalty. Honorius lived till he ſaw himſelf ſtripped of the greateſt part of his dominions; his capital taken by the Goths; the Huns ſeized of Panonia; the Alans, Suevi, and Vandals eſtabliſhed in Spain; and the Burgundians ſettled
in Gaul, where the Goths alſo fixed themſelves at laſt. After ſome time, the inhabitants of Rome alſo, being abandoned by the princes, feebly attempted to take the ſupreme power into their own hands. Armorica and Britain, ſeeing themſelves forſaken, began to regulate themſelves by their own laws. Thus the power was entirely broken, and thoſe who aſſumed the title, only encountered certain deſtruction. At length, even the very name of emperor of the Weſt expired upon the abdication of Auguſtus; and Odoacer, general of the Heruli, aſſumed the title of king of all Italy. Such was the end of this great empire, that had conquered the world with its arms, and inſtructed them with its wiſdom; that had riſen by temperance, and fell by luxury; that had been eſtabliſhed by a ſpirit of patriotiſm, and that fell into ruin when the empire was become ſo extenſive, that a Roman citizen was but an empty name. Its final diſſolution happened about five hundred and twenty-two years after the battle of Pharſalia, an hundred and forty-ſix after the removal of the imperial ſeat to Conſtantinople, and four hundred and ſeventy-ſix after the nativity of our Saviour.

div.head: INDEX.

list.item: ACTIUM.] The engagement there between Octavius and Anthony deſcribed, 78.
ADRIAN.] Elected emperour, 338. His character, and endowments, 338—340, 341. Viſits ſeveral parts of the empire, 343—347. His death, 351.
AGRIPPA POSTHUMUS.] Put to death by Tiberius, 122.
AGRIPPINA.] Her character, 208. Poiſons Claudius, 212. Diſſentions with her ſon, 217. Her death, 223.
ALARIC.] Invades Italy, 497. Lays ſiege to, and takes the city of Rome, 498, 499.
ALEXANDER.] Succeeds Heliogabalus, 419. His excellent character and government, ibid. 422. His death 424.

ANTHONY.] His character, 29. His oration to the people, 32. Oppoſes Octavius, 36. Declared an enemy to the ſtate, and an army ſent againſt him, 38. Unites with Octavius and Lepidus, 39. Defeats Brutus and Caſſius, 56. Diſpoſeth of ſeveral kingdoms, 61. Captivated by Cleopatra, 63. Marries Octavia, Auguſtus ſiſter, 66. Goes againſt the Parthians, 67. Gives Cleopatra ſeveral kingdoms, 72. His preparations for war with Octavius, 75. Defeated at Actium, 79. Returns to Alexandria, 80. Prepares to continue the war,
82. His fleet and part of his army revolt from him, 84. His death 86—88.
ANTONINUS PIUS.] His character, 352. His death, 356.
AQUADUCT.] That of Claudius deſcribed, 192.
ARIUS.] His hereſy condemned in a general council, and himſelf baniſhed, 486.

AUGUSTUS.] See Octavius.) His conduct on becoming ſolely poſſeſſed of the empire, 98. His conſultation with Agrippa and Maecenas, 101. His deceit and artifice to ſecure himſelf in the empire, 103, 104. Has the title of Auguſtus, with other honours, conferred on him, 104. Makes ſeveral edicts to ſuppreſs corruption in the ſenate, 105, licentiouſneſs in the people, and for ſeveral other purpoſes, 106, 107. Other inſtances of his good government, 107—109. Several nations who had revolted ſubdued, 110, 111. His domeſtic troubles, 112—114. Has twenty privycounſellors aſſigned him, 115. His death, 116. The honours paid to his memory, 118.

AURELIUS M.] Makes L. Verus his aſſociate, 356. His excellent government, 359. Defeats the Marcomani and Quadi, 361, 362. His army relieved by the prayers of a Chriſtian legion, 366. Avidius Caſſius rebels againſt him, 367. Goes againſt the Scythians, 373. His death, 375.
AURELIAN.] Choſen emperour by the army, 456. His character, 457. Defeats and takes Zenobia priſoner, 459. Inſtances of his juſtice and good government, 460. His death, 461.

list.head: B.
list.item:
BRITAIN.] The emperour Claudius perſuaded to invade it by Bericus, a native, 193. Revolts under
Nero, 238. Subdued by Paulinus, 239. Entirely ſubdued and civilized by Agricola, 302, and by him firſt diſcovered to be an iſland, 306.
BRUTUS.] Conſpires againſt Caeſar, 24. His character, 48. Defeat at Phillippi, and death, 56—59.
BYZANTIUM, or CONSTANTINOPLE.] Its ſituation deſcribed, 489.

list.head: C.
list.item: CALIGULA.] Why ſo called, 159. Begins his reign well, 161. His cruelty and other monſtrous enormities, 163—176. His expedition into Germany, 177. A conſpiracy formed againſt him, 182. His death, 186.
CARACALLA.] Kills Geta, 404. His other cruelties and extravagancies, 405—408. His death, 409.
CARACTACUS.] Defeated and carried to Rome, 195.
CARUS.] Choſen emperour by the army, 468. His death, 469.
CATO.] Retires from Pharſalia to Utica, 13. His death, 15. Character, 16.

CAESAR, JULIUS.] His character, 1. Purſues Pompey into Egypt, 2. His atchievements there, 3—8. Goes againſt Pharnaces, 9. Gains an eaſy victory, 10. Goes into Africa, 11. Defeats Scipio, 13. Returns in triumph to Rome, 17. Goes again into Spain, 18. Defeats Pompey's ſons at Munda, 20. His return to Rome, and conduct there, 21—23. A conſpiracy formed againſt him, 24. His death, 27.
CHRISTIANS.] A ſevere perſecution of them under Nero, 231. Domitian, 312. Trajan, 331. Aurelius, 361. Valerian, 448. Edicts iſſued in favour of them by Conſtantine, 483, 486.
CICERO, M. T.] Proſcribed and murdered, 42, 43.

CLAUDIUS.] Proclaimed emperour, 190. Begins his reign well, 191. Goes into Britain, 194. Puts ſeveral perſons to death, 198—201. An inſtance of his cruelty, 202. Marries Agrippina, 208. His death, 212.
CLAUDIUS, FLAVIUS.] His excellent character, atchievements and death, 453—456.
CLEOPATRA.] Deſcription and character of her, 5,—71. Flies from Actium, and is followed by Anthony, 78. Falls into the power of Auguſtus, 88. Her interview with him, 91. Her death, 93.
COMMODUS.] Succeeds Antonine, 376. His horrid cruelties and other enormities, 377—381. His death, 382.

CONSTANTINE THE GREAT.] Succeeds his father, 480. Converted to Chriſtianity, 482. Defeats Licinius, 485. Convenes a general council of biſhops, 486. Puts to death his wife and ſon, 486. Removes the ſeat of the empire to Byzantium, 488, 489. Divides the empire, 490. His death and character, 491.
CONSTANTIUS CHLORUS.] Divides the empire with Galerius, 476. His character, 477. Death, 478.
CREMUTIUS CORDUS.] Defeats the malice of Tiberius by a voluntary death, 140.

list.head: D.
list.item:
DECIUS.] Voted by the ſenate not inferiour to Trajan, 444. Gains a great victory over the
Goths, but is afterwards routed by the treachery of his general, 445. His death, ibid.
DICTATOR.] The title when aboliſhed, 105.
DIOCLESIAN.] His deſcent and character, 470. Subdues the Perſians, 472. Perſecutes the Chriſtians, 473. Reſigns the government, 474. His death, 475.

DOMITIAN.] The good begining of his reign, 304. Soon renders himſelf odious, 306. Several nations invade the empire, 307, 308. His arrogance and cruelties, ibid.—311. A conſpiracy formed againſt him, 314. His death, 316.

list.head: F.
list.item: FIDENAE.] Fifty thouſand perſons killed by the falling of an amphitheatre there, 144.
FUCINUS.] Deſcription of the draining this lake, 192.

list.head: G.
list.item: GALBA.] Declared emperour by the ſenate, 249. Is governed by his favourites, 257. Adopts Piſo to ſucceed him, 259. His death, 262.
GALERIUS.] Has the eaſtern parts of the empire for his ſhare of government, 476. His death, 479.
GALIENUS.] His deſolute conduct when choſen emperour, 450. Names of the thirty tyrants, who pretended to the empire, 451. His death, 452.
GALLUS.] By his treachery occaſions the defeat of the Roman army, 445, yet is declared emperour by the ſurviving part, 446. Buys a peace of the Goths, 446. His character and death, 447.
GAULS.] Several nations of them, 138. Are defeated, ibid.
GERMANICUS.] His character and atchievements in Germany, 126—128. The provinces of Aſia decreed to him, 132. Goes into Egypt, 133. His death, 135.
GLADIATORS.] Edicts made by Auguſtus to reſtrain the immoderate exhibition of them, 106.
GORDIAN.] He with his ſon created emperours, 431. Their deaths, 434.
GORDIAN the Younger.] His character, 439, and death, 441.

GOTHS.] Invade the empire, but are driven back by GORDIAN, 440. Make another invaſion, 442. Are defeated, but afterwards, thro' treachery, route the Roman army, 445. Oblige the Romans to purchaſe a peace, 446, which they ſoon break, and again invade the empire, ibid. Renew their inroads under Conſtantine, 489. Admited by Valens into Thrace, 495.

list.head: H.
list.item: HELIOGABALUS.] Choſen emperour, 414. His follies, prodigality and cruelty, ibid.—416. His death, 418.
HEROD AGRIPPA.] Judea reſtored to him by Claudius, 193.

list.head: J.
list.item: JERUSALEM.] Beſieged and taken, 287—291.
JEWS.] Revolt under Nero, 240; Trajan, 332; Adrian, 346.
JULIA, daughter of Auguſtus.] Her infamous conduct, 113. Baniſhed by Auguſtus, 114.
JULIAN.] Purchaſeth the empire, 389. His death, 393.
JULIUS SABINUS.] The ſeverity uſed to him, 293.
JULIUS VINDEX.] Revolts from Nero, and proclaims Galba emperour, 243. His death, 246.

list.head: L.
list.item: LEPIDUS.] Unites with Anthony and Octavius, 39. Has Spain aſſigned to him for his ſhare of the triumvirate, 41. In a new diviſion of the empire, has the provinces in Africa, 66. His army revolts to Octavius, 70.
LIVY.] His character as an hiſtorian, 97.
LONGINUS.] Put to death by Aurelian, 460.
LUCAN.] Put to death by Nero, 237.

list.head: M.
list.item: MACRINUS.] Choſen emperour, 411. His death, 413.
MAXIMIAN.] Made partner in the empire by Diocleſian, 471. With him reſigns the government, 474. His death, 475.
MAECENAS.] His advice to Auguſtus, 101.

MAXIMIN] His perſon and character, 425—428. Cruelty, 429, 430. The provinces of Africa revolt, and create Gordian emperour, 431, which the ſenate and people confirm, 432. Marches with his army towards Rome, 433. His death, 437.
MESSALINA.] Her infamous conduct, 197, 202—204. Her death, 207.

list.head: N.
list.item: NARCISSUS.] Procures the death of the empreſs Meſſalina, 204—206. Being proſecuted by Agrippina goes into voluntary exile, 211. His death 216.

NERO.] Marries Octavia, daughter of Claudius, 209. Proclaimed emperour, 214. The excellency
of his government at firſt, 216. Breaks out into extravagancies, 219. Marries Poppaea, wife of Otho, 220. Puts his mother to death, 223. Goes into Greece, 227. Returns to Rome, 228. His palace deſcribed, 232. Puts great numbers to death, 234, 237, 241, 242. Deſigns againſt him in Gaul, 243. The revolt becomes general, 246. His death, 251.
NERVA.] Choſen emperour by the ſenate, 317. His character, 318. His mild and good government, 319—322. His death, 323.

list.head: O.
list.item: OCTAVIUS.] Claims the inheritance of his uncle J. Caeſar, 35. His character, ibid. Oppoſed in his deſigns by Anthony, 36. Joins Anthony and Lepidus, 39. The ſenate confer on him abſolute power, 40. With Anthony and Lepidus forms the ſecond triumvirate, 41. Marches with Anthony againſt the conſpirators, 44. War commenced between him and Anthony, 65. Are reconciled, and divide the empire between them, 66. Deprives Lepidus of his ſhare in the triumvirate, 69. His preparations againſt Anthony, 75—77. Defeats him at Actium, 79. Goes againſt him to Alexandria, 83. Puts two ſons of Cleopatra to death, 90. Returns to Rome in triumph, 95. See AUGUSTUS.
OSTIA.] An haven made there by Claudius, 192.
OSTORIUS.] Succeeds Plautius in the government of Britain, 194. Defeats Caractacus, 195.

OTHO.] Declared emperour by the ſoldiery, 261. Begins his reign with a ſignal act of clemency and
juſtice, 263. Marches againſt Vitellius, 264. His army defeated by that of Vitellius, 267. His death, 269.

list.head: P.
list.item: PERTINAX.] His character, 383. Proclaimed emperour, 385. His death, 387.
PETRONIUS.] His character and death, 241.
PHILIP.] Declared emperour by the army and ſenate, 441. His death, 443.
PHILIPPI.] The battle fought there, and defeat of Brutus and Caſſius, 51—56.
PISO.] Accuſed before the ſenate of the death of Germanicus, and other crimes, 137. Kills himſelf, ibid.
PLUTARCH.] His excellent letter to Trajan, 325.
POMPEY, CNEIUS.] The reſpect paid to his memory by Caeſar, 3.
POMPEY, SEXTUS.] Defeated by Agrippa and ſlain, 68, 69.
PONTIUS PILATE.] Baniſhed into Gaul, 161. His death, ibid.
PORCIA, wife of Brutus.] Her death, 50.
PROBUS.] Choſen emperour by the army, 464. His character, atchievements and death, 465—467.
PUPIENUS.] Choſen emperour, with Albinus, by the ſenate, 435. Their deaths, 439.

list.head: Q.
list.item: QUINTILLIUS VARUS.] Cut off, with his whole army, by the Germans, 112.

list.head: R.
list.item:
ROME.] The wretched ſtate of it under the ſecond triumvirate, 42. In the begining of Auguſtus
reign, 95, 96. Revenues and number of its citizens, 96. None to be admited to the freedom of it without previous examination into their character, 106. The number of its inhabitants at a cenſus taken by Auguſtus, 115. Their luxury and prodigality, 156. Number of its inhabitants in the reign of Claudius, 212. A great part of it burnt, 231. Another fire and great plague, 302. When firſt governed by two ſovereigns, 356. Suffers greatly by a ſedition and fire, 435. Taken and pillaged by Alaric, 499, and again by Geſneric, 500.

list.head: S.
list.item: SEJANUS.] His character and promotion, 141. Procures the death of Germanicus two ſons, Nero and Druſus, 147. His death, 149.

SENATE.] Their ſervile adulation of Auguſtus, 104, 105. Several edicts made by him to ſuppreſs corruption in it, 105, 106. Maximin the firſt emperour who reigned without their concurrence, 429. Permited by Decius to chuſe a cenſor, 444.
SENECA.] Appointed tutor to Nero, 209. His death, 235.
SEVERUS.] Declared emperour by the ſenate, 394. His character, 395. Defeats Niger, 396. Albinus, 398. The Parthians, 399. Goes into Britain, 401. Dies there, 403.
SICILY.] Invaded by Octavius, 68.

list.head: T.
list.item: TACITUS.] Choſen emperour by the ſenate, 462. His character and death, 463.
TARSUS.] Anthony's firſt interview with Cleopatra there, 64.

TIBERIUS.] Succeeds Auguſtus in the empire, 121. His diſſimulation, and the ſervile flattery of the ſenate, 122—126. His deſigns againſt Germanicus, 129—132. Begins to appear in his natural character, 139. Retires to Capraea, 143. Puts great numbers to death, 149—152. Names Caligula for his ſucceſſor, 154. His death, 156.
TITUS.] Lays ſiege to Jeruſalem, 287. Takes it, 291. Enters Rome in triumph, with his father, 292. Succeeds him, 299. His exemplary government, ibid.—301. His death, 303.
TRAJAN.] Adopted by Nerva to ſucceed him, 322. His character, 324—326. Defeats the Dacians, 327—329. Parthians and other kingdoms, 333. His death, 336. The honours paid to his memory, 339.

list.head: V.
list.item: VALENS.] Admits the Goths to ſettle in Thrace, 495. Defeated and ſlain by them, 496.
VALERIAN.] Choſen emperour by the army, 448. His death, 449.
VERUS, LUCIUS.] His character and conduct, 356—358.
VESPASIAN.] Proclaimed emperour in the eaſt, 276. Sets out for Rome, 286. Corrects many abuſes, 292. His good government, character and death, 294—298.
VITELLIUS.] Proclaimed emperour in Germany, 263. By the ſenate, 270. The legions in the eaſt revolt, 275. His army routed at Cremona, 277. His death, 282.

list.head: X.
list.item: XANTHIANS.] Being beſieged by Brutus, deſtroy their city and themſelves, 46, 47.
